aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Hughes 369 Helicopter in Pasadena, California
Pasadena is a city in California.
The accident occurred on December 7, 2012, at 09:30 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Hughes 369 helicopter.
The defining event was classified as a cabin safety event.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Other work use.
The accident number was WPR13CA071.
The helicopter registration was N818CE.
The helicopter sustained substantial damage.
There was 1 person with no injuries.
The doors were removed from the helicopter before the flight.
The doors were removed to make it easier for passengers to board and exit the helicopter.
The pilot conducted a safety briefing.
During the safety briefing, the pilot took a headset from a pouch in the rear of the helicopter.
The pilot demonstrated how to wear the headsets during the safety briefing.
The pilot replaced the headset in the pouch after the demonstration.
The pilot did not tell passengers that headsets needed to be replaced in the pouch after landing.
The pilot did not inform passengers about dangers of loose headsets in a doors-off configuration.
The helicopter transported two passengers to a work site location.
After landing at the work site, the right rear passenger exited the helicopter.
The right rear passenger placed the headset on a hook located behind the front seats.
The helicopter departed from the work site.
Approximately 3 to 5 minutes after departing the work site, the pilot felt something strike the helicopter.
The helicopter was at an elevation of about 1,000 feet above ground level when the pilot felt something strike it.
The pilot landed the helicopter after feeling something strike it.
Upon inspection, the pilot discovered the right rear headset was missing.
The pilot discovered damage to the leading edge of the tail rotor.
The operator reported the tail rotor drive shaft was slightly egg shaped at its aft end.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be an unsecured headset striking the leading edge of a tail rotor blade.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the pilot's inadequate safety briefing was a contributing factor to the accident.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Pasadena, California

## Date & Time: 
December 7, 2012, 09:30 Local

## Aircraft:
Hughes 369

## Defining Event:
Cabin safety event

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Other work use

## Accident Number:
WPR13CA071

## Registration:
N818CE

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

Prior to the flight, the doors were removed in order to make it easier for the passengers to board and exit the helicopter. During the safety briefing, the pilot took a headset from a pouch in the rear of the helicopter, demonstrated how to wear the headsets, and then replaced it. The pilot did not tell the passengers that the headsets needed to be replaced in the pouch after landing and before exiting the helicopter. Additionally, the pilot did not make the passengers aware of the danger associated with loose headsets in the back of the helicopter in a doors-off configuration.

After the two passengers were transported to a work site location, the right rear passenger exited the helicopter and placed the headset on the hook located behind the front seats. After departing the site, about 3 to 5 minutes later while en route at an elevation of about 1,000 feet above ground level, the pilot felt something strike the helicopter. After landing and upon inspecting the helicopter, the pilot discovered that the right rear headset was missing and that the leading edge of the tail rotor had been damaged. Upon further inspection of the helicopter, the operator reported that the tail rotor drive shaft was found to be slightly egg shaped at its aft end.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be: An unsecured headset, which struck the leading edge of a tail rotor blade. Contributing to the accident was the pilot's inadequate safety briefing.

---
